#NLP4Gov: the first Belgian NLP Hackathon



Have you always been keen to apply language technology to improve society? This is your chance!

From Monday 8 October to Wednesday 17 October NLP Town is organizing a Natural Language Processing Hackathon with a focus on legal and administrative NLP. The hackathon is hosted by Informatie Vlaanderen and sponsored by technology leader SAP. Start-ups, students, professional and hobby NLPers will get the opportunity to develop prototype NLP applications that can make our government smarter and more efficient.

The hackathon takes the form of a sprint, where teams get 10 days to work on a focused project. Every team should consist of two to five people. On Monday 8 October, the first day of the sprint, our government will present the most pressing use cases where NLP could help them out. After this introduction, the teams can start designing and implementing their applications. All day, government officials will be available to answer their questions and to help make their solutions as useful as possible.

After this introductory day, teams get just over a week to implement their solutions. On Wednesday 17 October, they come back together to finalize their applications and prepare their pitches. In the morning, government officials will again be present to lend a helping hand. In the afternoon, the teams showcase their NLP solutions. A jury will select the most promising applications and award three prizes, provided by technology sponsor SAP: a first prize (€3.000), a startup prize (€2.000), and a student team prize (€2.000).

Participation is free, but registration is compulsory. Every team member has to register individually. There is a maximum of 100 participants, so don’t wait until it’s too late. You can register here.

Where: Dirk Bouts Building Vlaamse Overheid, Leuven, Belgium
When: Monday 8 October and Wednesday 17 October, from 10am to 5pm
Who: NLPers in teams of 2 to 5 people
More information (in Dutch): here

Organizer

NLP Town provides consultancy and software development in Natural Language Processing. We help companies unlock the potential in unstructured text.

Sponsor

SAP is the exclusive technology sponsor of the hackathon. As the 4th largest software company in the world, SAP supports companies and organizations in their digital transformation path and helps them become ‘Intelligent Enterprises’, which turn digital challenges into optimal business results.

SAP will provide participants with credits for their Cloud Platform, so that the teams can use these resources during the hackathon. On October 1st and 4th there will be two webinars to introduce participants to the platform. To register for these webinars, you can e-mail philippe.nemery@sap.com.

Program

Monday 8 October
9:00-10:00 Doors Open
10:00-12:00 Introduction to the hackathon and the use cases
12:00-13:00 Lunch
13:00-17:00 Teams start developing their prototypes. Government officials are present to help them develop the most relevant applications possible.

Wednesday 17 October
9:00-12:00 Teams finish their prototype and prepare their pitch. Government officials are again present to lend a helping hand.
12:00-13:00 Lunch
13:00-16:00 Pitches
16:00-16:30 Jury deliberation
16:30-18:00 Award ceremony and reception

Generating Genre Fiction with Deep Learning



Thesaurus Construction


Thesauri are the foundation for many Information Retrieval systems. Search engines, for example, extend the queries of their users by adding synonyms and related keywords. In my PhD dissertation, I explored novel ways of automatically discovering such words with similar meanings, even across dialects and different languages. The output of these methods can harness Information Retrieval systems against language variation in their text collections.


Text categorization


If you have a spam filter, you’re already using text categorization every day. More advanced applications are able to recognize topics such as politics, football or music with very high precision. For example, if you’re a media company, you can use these methods to alert users about new content on topics they’re really interested in, or you can customize the content of your website and search results to your customers’ personal profiles.


Sentiment analysis


Thanks to the popularity of blogs, social media, and review sites, more and more people are making themselves heard. Your users and customers write reviews of your products on their blogs, or share their opinion about your company on Twitter. Sentiment Analysis identifies the feelings behind these messages: it classifies them as positive or negative, or detects emotions such as anger and joy. It allows you to know your customers better and to respond to their needs more successfully.


Semantic Search


These days users expect more from a search engine than a system that simply returns a list of documents with the words they typed in. Through a careful application of Natural Language Processing, modern search engines aim to truly understand the needs of their users. They scan their text collection for synonyms, learn the topics of a text, or identify entities such as people and places and discover the relations between them. In these ways, they extract the information present in their documents, and present it to their users in novel ways.


Machine Translation


There is more to Machine Translation than Google Translate. I have extensive experience training and optimizing state-of-the-art MT systems such as Moses and Phrasal, which allow companies to build customized translation solutions. By training these systems on their own texts or those of their customers, companies can achieve far superior performance and bring down translation effort and cost.


Information Extraction


Information Extraction is the task of identifying useful information in unstructured documents. In the past I have developed methods for finding definitions of terms in legislation, for identifying entities (people, organizations, locations) and the relations between them, and for transforming job ads and CVs to structured tables whose values can be matched. In this way, Natural Language Processing helps turn large collections of unstructured text into actionable insights.
